file_content.text: Stop! You must not steal that precious data, I implore you!
Were I not locked in Grathan's science dormitory, I'd face you in person. I can only hope the passion of my plea convinces you.
I'm Lanniter Droge, lead researcher of Lord Grathan's cybernetics division. That data you're stealing is my life's work.
You're another of Grathan's prisoners, right? How is this your life's work?
Aren't you a slave?
I'm no prisoner. I volunteered for this project because Grathan alone had the resources to help me achieve my goal.
So what?
I realize you have no reason to indulge me. Thank you for the chance to defend my creation.
If I were you, I'd be sad.
Please, you don't fully grasp the significance of my work. Let me explain.
I'm the creator of Project ARC--Automatic Regenerating Cybernetics. I've developed mechanical body parts that grow and heal like actual flesh and bone.
Making better soldiers is an obvious application--but my dream is to give these lifelike replacement limbs to the victims of war.
The more powerful our army, the faster the Republic falls.
We need better soldiers.
What about the common Imperial citizens maimed by this war? Surely they matter as well.
Your masters should determine how this technology is used.
That's not your decision.
Then... then I leave that determination to you, my lord. You're obviously more powerful than Grathan.
Idealism will only get you killed.
Stop dreaming.
The galaxy brings many opportunities to make a credit, but so few to make a difference. I have to try.
Why do you inventor types always overthink things?
Typical scientist.
It's a hazard of being intelligent--but it doesn't change the fact I'm right.
I admire your dream.
You understand! Wonderful. Then hope remains.
Sorry, doesn't sway me.
Don't you see? This technology should be used to heal, not create more killing machines!
Lord Grathan encrypted my research notes to prevent duplication, but that data spike will download everything and erase the original. You're taking the only copy.
Please, don't steal that data. Allow me to continue healing the sick.
I was promised a lot of credits for this, and I plan to collect.
Sorry, pal. [Steal the data]
I hope you can live with the knowledge you failed to make the galaxy a better place. Enjoy your filthy credits, thief.
Come here and call me "thief" to my face, worm.
Say that again--I dare you.
No thank you, I have an aversion to dying.
What do I care about bettering the galaxy?
Won't bother me at all.
You'd think even Sith would tire of wallowing in corruption, eventually.
The first thing an Imperial agent develops is an immunity to guilt.
Your words are harmless.
Then you willingly murdered your conscience. How pathetic.
Credits always make my galaxy a better place.
Thanks, I will.
I'm surrounded by scoundrels and profiteers.
I pity you, really. Good day.
Healing the unfortunate is worth more than money.
I won't steal the data.
Wonderful! You've restored my faith in others. Although, we still have a problem.
Unless they think you succeeded, whoever sent you will certainly try again. Download some other data from that console--anything, it doesn't matter.
Deliver the spike as you promised. By the time your contact realizes the truth, my real data will be safely secured elsewhere.
You're lucky I'm indulging you.
You owe me for this.
I'm thankful I caught you on a good day.
How sinisterly plotted. You may have missed your true calling.
Clever.
Comes from years of working for a sociopath. Doesn't mean I want to be one.
Don't worry, I'll make the deception absolutely convincing.
Leave everything to me.
Yes, I sense your talents will come in handy here.
If you tell anyone I did this, I'll deny it.
Keep quiet about this.
Rest assured I'll keep your virtuous nature a secret.
Is that all?
Knowing that my life's work is safe is all I need.
Enough, already.
I'm very fortunate you were the one who came to do this.
Thank you again. Deliver the false data and everything should be alright.
What a pointless chat.
Guilt has a funny way of catching up to us when we least expect it.
This wasn't personal.
